payload.name: satisficing
payload.core: Seek a solution that is good enough given time, compute, or information limits rather than globally optimal. When optimization costs exceed benefits, satisficing is the rational approach.
out: stopping rule for when to halt search
proc: accept first candidate meeting threshold; stop search
if no candidate meets threshold, relax threshold or extend budget
document why threshold level is appropriate for context
check: stopping rule defined before search begins
threshold neither trivially low nor disguised optimization

diff.optimization: optimization seeks global best; satisficing accepts first good-enough solution
diff.heuristic: heuristics are rules of thumb; satisficing is deliberate threshold-based stopping
diff.value-of-information: VOI decides when to stop gathering info; satisficing decides when to stop searching for solutions

fail.name: threshold miscalibration
signals: consistently accepting mediocre outcomes (threshold too low)
search never terminates (threshold too high, disguised optimization)
threshold set post-hoc to justify chosen solution
no explicit stopping rule; ad-hoc termination
mitigations: benchmark threshold against historical acceptable outcomes
time-box search with forced acceptance of best-so-far
periodic threshold review with stakeholder input

ex.scenario: Select vendor for non-critical SaaS tool. Budget: 2 hours research. Threshold: meets 5 must-have features, <$50/seat, positive reviews.
steps: list 5 must-have features and price ceiling
accept vendor 3; stop search at 45 minutes
document: threshold met, remaining budget returned to other tasks
